title: How to Mod Podge Paper to Wood

steps.headline: Choose a suitable object for the project.
steps.description: Wood objects that work the best for this project include boxes, frames, and wooden letters. Avoid round or beveled shapes, such as balls or candlesticks, as this will cause the paper to crinkle.

steps.headline: Sand away any rough patches on your wood piece.
steps.description: Most blank wood pieces from the arts and crafts store come pre-sanded, but some may have rough patches. If you need to, sand those rough patches away with a medium to fine-grit sandpaper. Be sure to sand with the grain rather than against it. If your piece has a very rough grain, you will need to sand it smooth first.

steps.headline: Wipe the wood piece down to get rid of the sanding dust.
steps.description: A tack cloth will work the best for this, but you can use a damp cloth as well. You don't have to do this if you skipped the sanding, but it would still be a good idea to do so. Many store-bought items contain a thin layer of dust that may prevent the Mod Podge from sticking.

steps.headline: Paint the wood piece a solid color, if desired.
steps.description: If you will be covering the entire wood piece with paper, you can skip this step. If you will covering just one side, however, consider painting it first. Be sure to leave the side you'll be covering blank, however! Acrylic paint or spray paint will work the best for this. Use a color that matches the design on your paper.

steps.headline: Allow the paint to dry, if you applied it.
steps.description: How long this takes depends on the type of paint you used. Most spray paints and acrylic paints will only need about 20 minutes in which to dry. If you need to apply a second coat of paint, let the first one dry before doing so. Allow the second one to dry as well before moving on.

steps.headline: Choose some suitable paper.
steps.description: Scrapbooking paper works the best for this. If your wood piece is much larger than the scrapbooking paper, consider using wrapping paper instead--just make sure that it is not obvious! Another alternative is to create your design on the computer, then print it out using an inkjet printer.

steps.headline: Seal the paper with clear, acrylic sealer, if needed.
steps.description: You only need to do this if you chose very thin scrapbooking paper, or if you printed the paper using an ink jet printer. If you used regular scrapbooking paper, you can skip this step. Spray the front of the paper first. Let it dry, then spray the back. The finish of the spray does not matter because you will be applying Mod Podge over it.

steps.headline: Trace your wood piece onto the back of the paper.
steps.description: Flip the paper over so that you can see the back. Set the wood piece on top of it, and trace around it with a pencil. Repeat this step for each side of the paper you will be covering.

steps.headline: Cut the traced scrapbooking paper.
steps.description: It would be a good idea to cut the paper out just outside the lines that you drew. This way, you will reduce the risk of cutting the paper too small and ending up with gaps. Repeat this step for each shape that you traced. You can cut the paper with scissors, but a craft blade will give you more precision. If you are careful and precise, you can use just inside the lines that you drew.

parts.name: Mod Podging the Paper to the Wood

steps.headline: Pour the Mod Podge into a bowl or container, if desired.
steps.description: If you are working an a small piece, you don't need to do this. If you are working on a larger piece, however, you will need to upgrade to a larger brush. Pouring the Mod Podge into some sort of container will make it easier to access. Bowls, clean and empty yogurt tubs, and plastic food containers (ie: Tupperware) work well for this.

steps.headline: Apply a thin coat of Mod Podge to the wood piece.
steps.description: You can do this with a flat, wide paintbrush, a foam brush, or even a foam roller. Be sure to cover the entire surface, from edge to edge. If your paper is thick and sturdy, it would be a good idea to apply a thin coat to the back as well. If you are applying Mod Podge to your paper, work on a larger piece of scrap paper so that you don't get your work surface dirty. If you are covering multiple sides on your object, choose one side to work on first.

steps.headline: Place the paper onto the Mod Podged surface and smooth it down.
steps.description: Set the paper lightly onto the surface first. Nudge it into place, if needed, then gently pat it down. Use a squeegee for small objects, or a rubber/silicone roller/brayer for large objects. Work your way from the center of the object outward. Mod Podge makes special rollers for smoothing down paper. You can typically find it alongside the other Mod Podge supplies in the arts and crafts store. If any Mod Podge leaks out from under the paper, wipe it off with a damp paper towel.

steps.headline: Allow the paper to dry before adding a second coat.
steps.description: Let the paper dry for 15 to 20 minutes first, then apply a second coat of Mod Podge on top. It is very important that you wait, otherwise the first layer won't cure properly. If you have any overhanging edges, trim them off now with a craft blade. You can also sand them off with sandpaper.

steps.headline: Add some cut-outs, if desired.
steps.description:
If your paper had a pale, subtle, or simple background, you can make it look more interesting by Mod Podging shapes cut from other scrapbook paper on top. Make sure that the shapes work with your design, however! Here's what to do:
Choose a paper with a large pattern on it, such as birds or flowers. Cut the individual birds or flowers out. Apply Mod Podge to the back of each shape. Smooth the shapes onto your covered wood piece. Overlap shapes for an interesting effect.

steps.headline: Apply two more coats of Mod Podge, then let it dry completely.
steps.description: As before, keep these layers thin. Allow each layer to dry before adding the next one. Once you apply the last layer, allow it to dry completely. Mod Podge typically has a drying time and a curing time. Refer to the label on your bottle for specific times.

steps.headline: Finish the other sides, if needed.
steps.description: If you are Mod Podging paper to a box, you can apply the paper to the other sides. Use the same method and technique as before, working one side at a time. You can do two sides that are opposite each other, as long as they are not touching anything.

steps.headline: Embellish the finished piece, if desired.
steps.description: You can leave your Mod Podge piece as-is, or you can embellish it further with buttons, fake flowers, or ribbon. Make sure that the embellishments go with your design, however. For something simple, use paper scrapbooking embellishments. Peel the baking off of the foam sticker on the back, then apply it to the piece. Outline larger shapes or edges with glitter glue. If you don't have glitter glue, use regular white glue, then sprinkle extra-fine glitter on top. Apply a light layer of white paint with a dry brush for a vintage look. Thread embroidery floss through the holes on a button, then glue the button to the piece so it looks stitched on. Mix extra-fine glitter into Mod Podge, then apply a final coat for extra sparkle.

text:
Preparing the Wood Choose a suitable object for the project. Wood objects that work the best for this project include boxes, frames, and wooden letters. Avoid round or beveled shapes, such as balls or candlesticks, as this will cause the paper to crinkle. Sand away any rough patches on your wood piece. Most blank wood pieces from the arts and crafts store come pre-sanded, but some may have rough patches. If you need to, sand those rough patches away with a medium to fine-grit sandpaper. Be sure to sand with the grain rather than against it. If your piece has a very rough grain, you will need to sand it smooth first. Wipe the wood piece down to get rid of the sanding dust. A tack cloth will work the best for this, but you can use a damp cloth as well. You don't have to do this if you skipped the sanding, but it would still be a good idea to do so. Many store-bought items contain a thin layer of dust that may prevent the Mod Podge from sticking. Paint the wood piece a solid color, if desired. If you will be covering the entire wood piece with paper, you can skip this step. If you will covering just one side, however, consider painting it first. Be sure to leave the side you'll be covering blank, however! Acrylic paint or spray paint will work the best for this. Use a color that matches the design on your paper. Allow the paint to dry, if you applied it. How long this takes depends on the type of paint you used. Most spray paints and acrylic paints will only need about 20 minutes in which to dry. If you need to apply a second coat of paint, let the first one dry before doing so. Allow the second one to dry as well before moving on. Preparing the Paper Choose some suitable paper. Scrapbooking paper works the best for this. If your wood piece is much larger than the scrapbooking paper, consider using wrapping paper instead--just make sure that it is not obvious! Another alternative is to create your design on the computer, then print it out using an inkjet printer. Seal the paper with clear, acrylic sealer, if needed. You only need to do this if you chose very thin scrapbooking paper, or if you printed the paper using an ink jet printer. If you used regular scrapbooking paper, you can skip this step. Spray the front of the paper first. Let it dry, then spray the back. The finish of the spray does not matter because you will be applying Mod Podge over it. Trace your wood piece onto the back of the paper. Flip the paper over so that you can see the back. Set the wood piece on top of it, and trace around it with a pencil. Repeat this step for each side of the paper you will be covering. Cut the traced scrapbooking paper. It would be a good idea to cut the paper out just outside the lines that you drew. This way, you will reduce the risk of cutting the paper too small and ending up with gaps. Repeat this step for each shape that you traced. You can cut the paper with scissors, but a craft blade will give you more precision. If you are careful and precise, you can use just inside the lines that you drew. Mod Podging the Paper to the Wood Pour the Mod Podge into a bowl or container, if desired. If you are working an a small piece, you don't need to do this. If you are working on a larger piece, however, you will need to upgrade to a larger brush. Pouring the Mod Podge into some sort of container will make it easier to access. Bowls, clean and empty yogurt tubs, and plastic food containers (ie: Tupperware) work well for this. Apply a thin coat of Mod Podge to the wood piece. You can do this with a flat, wide paintbrush, a foam brush, or even a foam roller. Be sure to cover the entire surface, from edge to edge. If your paper is thick and sturdy, it would be a good idea to apply a thin coat to the back as well. If you are applying Mod Podge to your paper, work on a larger piece of scrap paper so that you don't get your work surface dirty. If you are covering multiple sides on your object, choose one side to work on first. Place the paper onto the Mod Podged surface and smooth it down. Set the paper lightly onto the surface first. Nudge it into place, if needed, then gently pat it down. Use a squeegee for small objects, or a rubber/silicone roller/brayer for large objects. Work your way from the center of the object outward. Mod Podge makes special rollers for smoothing down paper. You can typically find it alongside the other Mod Podge supplies in the arts and crafts store. If any Mod Podge leaks out from under the paper, wipe it off with a damp paper towel. Allow the paper to dry before adding a second coat. Let the paper dry for 15 to 20 minutes first, then apply a second coat of Mod Podge on top. It is very important that you wait, otherwise the first layer won't cure properly. If you have any overhanging edges, trim them off now with a craft blade. You can also sand them off with sandpaper. Add some cut-outs, if desired. If your paper had a pale, subtle, or simple background, you can make it look more interesting by Mod Podging shapes cut from other scrapbook paper on top. Make sure that the shapes work with your design, however! Here's what to do:
Choose a paper with a large pattern on it, such as birds or flowers. Cut the individual birds or flowers out. Apply Mod Podge to the back of each shape. Smooth the shapes onto your covered wood piece. Overlap shapes for an interesting effect. Apply two more coats of Mod Podge, then let it dry completely. As before, keep these layers thin. Allow each layer to dry before adding the next one. Once you apply the last layer, allow it to dry completely. Mod Podge typically has a drying time and a curing time. Refer to the label on your bottle for specific times. Finish the other sides, if needed. If you are Mod Podging paper to a box, you can apply the paper to the other sides. Use the same method and technique as before, working one side at a time. You can do two sides that are opposite each other, as long as they are not touching anything. Embellish the finished piece, if desired. You can leave your Mod Podge piece as-is, or you can embellish it further with buttons, fake flowers, or ribbon. Make sure that the embellishments go with your design, however. For something simple, use paper scrapbooking embellishments. Peel the baking off of the foam sticker on the back, then apply it to the piece. Outline larger shapes or edges with glitter glue. If you don't have glitter glue, use regular white glue, then sprinkle extra-fine glitter on top. Apply a light layer of white paint with a dry brush for a vintage look. Thread embroidery floss through the holes on a button, then glue the button to the piece so it looks stitched on. Mix extra-fine glitter into Mod Podge, then apply a final coat for extra sparkle.
sentences: Preparing the Wood Choose a suitable object for the project.
Wood objects that work the best for this project include boxes, frames, and wooden letters.
Avoid round or beveled shapes, such as balls or candlesticks, as this will cause the paper to crinkle.
Sand away any rough patches on your wood piece.
Most blank wood pieces from the arts and crafts store come pre-sanded, but some may have rough patches.
If you need to, sand those rough patches away with a medium to fine-grit sandpaper.
Be sure to sand with the grain rather than against it.
If your piece has a very rough grain, you will need to sand it smooth first.
Wipe the wood piece down to get rid of the sanding dust.
A tack cloth will work the best for this, but you can use a damp cloth as well.
You don't have to do this if you skipped the sanding, but it would still be a good idea to do so.
Many store-bought items contain a thin layer of dust that may prevent the Mod Podge from sticking.
Paint the wood piece a solid color, if desired.
If you will be covering the entire wood piece with paper, you can skip this step.
If you will covering just one side, however, consider painting it first.
Be sure to leave the side you'll be covering blank, however!
Acrylic paint or spray paint will work the best for this.
Use a color that matches the design on your paper.
Allow the paint to dry, if you applied it.
How long this takes depends on the type of paint you used.
Most spray paints and acrylic paints will only need about 20 minutes in which to dry.
If you need to apply a second coat of paint, let the first one dry before doing so.
Allow the second one to dry as well before moving on.
Preparing the Paper Choose some suitable paper.
Scrapbooking paper works the best for this.
If your wood piece is much larger than the scrapbooking paper, consider using wrapping paper instead--just make sure that it is not obvious!
Another alternative is to create your design on the computer, then print it out using an inkjet printer.
Seal the paper with clear, acrylic sealer, if needed.
You only need to do this if you chose very thin scrapbooking paper, or if you printed the paper using an ink jet printer.
If you used regular scrapbooking paper, you can skip this step.
Spray the front of the paper first.
Let it dry, then spray the back.
The finish of the spray does not matter because you will be applying Mod Podge over it.
Trace your wood piece onto the back of the paper.
Flip the paper over so that you can see the back.
Set the wood piece on top of it, and trace around it with a pencil.
Repeat this step for each side of the paper you will be covering.
Cut the traced scrapbooking paper.
It would be a good idea to cut the paper out just outside the lines that you drew.
This way, you will reduce the risk of cutting the paper too small and ending up with gaps.
Repeat this step for each shape that you traced.
You can cut the paper with scissors, but a craft blade will give you more precision.
If you are careful and precise, you can use just inside the lines that you drew.
Mod Podging the Paper to the Wood Pour the Mod Podge into a bowl or container, if desired.
If you are working an a small piece, you don't need to do this.
If you are working on a larger piece, however, you will need to upgrade to a larger brush.
Pouring the Mod Podge into some sort of container will make it easier to access.
Bowls, clean and empty yogurt tubs, and plastic food containers (ie: Tupperware) work well for this.
Apply a thin coat of Mod Podge to the wood piece.
You can do this with a flat, wide paintbrush, a foam brush, or even a foam roller.
Be sure to cover the entire surface, from edge to edge.
If your paper is thick and sturdy, it would be a good idea to apply a thin coat to the back as well.
If you are applying Mod Podge to your paper, work on a larger piece of scrap paper so that you don't get your work surface dirty.
If you are covering multiple sides on your object, choose one side to work on first.
Place the paper onto the Mod Podged surface and smooth it down.
Set the paper lightly onto the surface first.
Nudge it into place, if needed, then gently pat it down.
Use a squeegee for small objects, or a rubber/silicone roller/brayer for large objects.
Work your way from the center of the object outward.
Mod Podge makes special rollers for smoothing down paper.
You can typically find it alongside the other Mod Podge supplies in the arts and crafts store.
If any Mod Podge leaks out from under the paper, wipe it off with a damp paper towel.
Allow the paper to dry before adding a second coat.
Let the paper dry for 15 to 20 minutes first, then apply a second coat of Mod Podge on top.
It is very important that you wait, otherwise the first layer won't cure properly.
If you have any overhanging edges, trim them off now with a craft blade.
You can also sand them off with sandpaper.
Add some cut-outs, if desired.
If your paper had a pale, subtle, or simple background, you can make it look more interesting by Mod Podging shapes cut from other scrapbook paper on top.
Make sure that the shapes work with your design, however!

Here's what to do:
Choose a paper with a large pattern on it, such as birds or flowers.
Cut the individual birds or flowers out.
Apply Mod Podge to the back of each shape.
Smooth the shapes onto your covered wood piece.
Overlap shapes for an interesting effect.
Apply two more coats of Mod Podge, then let it dry completely.
As before, keep these layers thin.
Allow each layer to dry before adding the next one.
Once you apply the last layer, allow it to dry completely.
Mod Podge typically has a drying time and a curing time.
Refer to the label on your bottle for specific times.
Finish the other sides, if needed.
If you are Mod Podging paper to a box, you can apply the paper to the other sides.
Use the same method and technique as before, working one side at a time.
You can do two sides that are opposite each other, as long as they are not touching anything.
Embellish the finished piece, if desired.
You can leave your Mod Podge piece as-is, or you can embellish it further with buttons, fake flowers, or ribbon.
Make sure that the embellishments go with your design, however.
For something simple, use paper scrapbooking embellishments.
Peel the baking off of the foam sticker on the back, then apply it to the piece.
Outline larger shapes or edges with glitter glue.
If you don't have glitter glue, use regular white glue, then sprinkle extra-fine glitter on top.
Apply a light layer of white paint with a dry brush for a vintage look.
Thread embroidery floss through the holes on a button, then glue the button to the piece so it looks stitched on.
Mix extra-fine glitter into Mod Podge, then apply a final coat for extra sparkle.
